ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course provided me with he opportunity to learn more about the intersection of gender and agriculture, which is very important yet not widely covered issue. Besides aspects of food security were well covered throughout the course. I believe Yale needs more courses on these matters and I've encountered only this one. Professor Doss was always very helpful with explaining the material and recommending additional sources for studying.

The class is mostly too basic for students at a graduate school level and the readings are too few in number. The assignments are very straightforward and require exceptionally little analysis or the development of personal thoughts and opinions.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The readings and assignments. I learned a lot about ag data from the assignments.
Good overview of relevant issues related to food security.
I liked lectures of Prof.Doss and the reading material which helped improving my understanding of the curriculum.
Using the FAO data was really interesting. Good combination of production, nutrition...

I liked the breadth of the material it covered and the neutral approach towards many politically charged policy issues. The breadth made it great for an outsider like me who had no background in the study of agricultural development and food security. the approach was very open minded and quite interdisciplinary. It's proven to be of practical help also, as I have discovered good resources for answering future questions. in addition, the class environment was very pleasant.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: A better classroom and more students would improve the lectures. Also, the two assignments should be split into four so that students can get feedback and adjust as the semester moves forward.
Readings could be more effectively incorporated into the course. Class time should engage students more actively with questions beyond the material presented.
I believe class participation part needs to have a bigger weight in the grade as this will make the classes more interactive.
The assignments need to be changed to better fit the overall goals and themes of the class. Right now they feel more like a lesson in using Excel.
I would have liked to have had more on trade policy, the role of the WTO with subsidies. More on public policy.

1) It would be nice to watch documentaries as assignment once in a while. 2) There could be more emphasis on the type of non-agricultural work done in agricultural households, as we have often discussed household's investment decisions. 3) there could be some more demographics and migration considerations: How do households decide how many children to have? When do male or female members leave the household to work in non-agricultural jobs? What are the projections for the share of the global population living in the countryside in the next 100 years? Why is it important to study agricultural production systems?

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Not relevant.
We had many discussions throughout the course, yet I wish we had a bit more of them.
It was very effective

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am very interested in developmental economics and food production. So this course fits right in with my interests.
I believe this course helped me a lot in my program. Thanks to this course I realized what exactly I would like to concentrate my research efforts on.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above.
I was interested in strengthening my knowledge of microeconomics and understanding issues relevant to food security.
I was looking for the course related to the food security.
I wanted to explore a topic with which I was not familiar

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
No, I felt I gained few skills and much of the knowledge I could have gotten from just reading the slides (without attending class).

They exceeded my expectations as thanks to this course I have been managed to refine the idea of my research project. It became possible as we covered different aspects of food security and agriculture throughout the semester. Inclusion of gender issues in the perimeter was especially helpful.

No. The skills involved in this class are very basic and present mostly uncritical views of issues that most students are already well aware of. More focus should be placed on critical thinking, analysis and alternative explanations.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I enjoyed the group work. I wish I had started on the group project earlier in the semester.
It was useful to interact with my peers.
Advantages - I was able to learn from my colleagues, disadvantages - as not everyone had the same motivation some members of the group had to do significantly more than others.
The work group allowed us to pool our combined experience and was the situation where i learned the most in this class.
I think it was a good choice to make the policy memo a group project. It gave more space for discussion.

It was great to learn from other's experience, as we had very different backgrounds. But our interests were also a bit different, so sometimes we were talking a bit past each other. It's a trade off, but overall I think it's been helpful

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Look at the syllabus to see if it's right for you.
Do the readings and participate in the class discussions.
Take it!
